I don't think the chart is particularly useful, there are better ways to get stock price charts. It's anyway misnamed, it's a plain line chart, not a scatterplot. That's a good thing, a price scatterplot wouldn't be very useful either. 

I'm all for getting rid of the different intervals, they don't even change the displayed data, just the numbers along the X axis, and those numbers are themselves pretty useless.
However using the dates of the prices to set the vertical lines makes for a strange-looking plot and it's going to get congested for plots with either a long period or showing frequent quotes. I think it would be better to break the period up into some consistent number of intervals and put date labels on each interval.

```
gnc_commodity_table_destroy(gnc_commodity_table_get_table(m_book));
```

> During development it is desirable not to have to make the code
warning free for every build, as that slows down the testing cycle.

Nope. We set -Werror on those warnings because we don't want anything committed that emits those warnings.

> We do not control the contents of these files directly,
so we don't want to deal with compiler warnings as errors.

Actually we do, they're generated from code in `.i` files and those aren't checked until the resulting SWIG file is compiled.

That's a lot of work, thanks for making the effort. We're trying to reduce our dependencies on GLib, particularly in C++ code, so I'd prefer not to use G_BEGIN/END_DECLS macros. One alternative would be to recreate them with GNC_BEGIN/END_DECLS, but that would require having a common header that gets included everywhere and we don't have one of those and it seems silly to introduce one just for a single macro pair. The other alternative is to replace the macros with their expansion, i.e. `G_BEGIN_DECLS` with `#ifdef __cplusplus…`. Please do the latter.

Nearly all of the comments apply throughout, not just at the locus of the comment.
Beyond the comments, you need to rethink this. 

Mixing the usages of C structs and C++ classes makes for a hard to read and hard to reason about design. C++ classes should each [do a single job](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-responsibility_principle) and should present a functional interface that performs the job, not be a bundle of variables. When you want a bundle of variables use a struct *with no functions*.

Model, View, and Controller are categories for classes; they should be single classes only in the simplest designs. For example instead of a single StockAssistantView class you might have a class for each page in the assistant and each page class might have its own controller; see the next item.

Note that in the original [MVC design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model–view–controller) the view was the display driver and the controller was the keyboard driver. Modern GUI frameworks like Gtk handle both ends of that, so a more useful way to think of the separation in GnuCash terms is that the View is what Gtk does, the Model is what's in the Engine, and the Controller is whatever (ideally minimal) code is needed in between. This is sometimes called [Model-View-Adapter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model–view–adapter). In practice with Gtk the View classes would contain the Gtk-dependent code and provide an abstracted interface through which the controller could get and set widget values and register signal handlers. The model lives lilbgnucash, and the controller uses the libgnucash API to manipulate data in response to the inputs or to retrieve data to display in the view.

Keep in mind that Gtk itself has its own class hierarchy and memory management system. You want only the thinnest possible C++ wrapper or none at all. Note that a GObject* is already a reference-counted shared pointer. C++ std::shared_ptr and std::unique_ptr require destructor parameters to work correctly with them.

Combining declarations and function implementations the way you have is incredibly hard to read. It's suitable only for simple classes with a few short member functions where short means no more than 3 lines and a few means no more than 5.

Huge classes with more than a dozen or so member variables indicates multiple responsibilities. Consider splitting such a class up into smaller classes and composing the smaller classes into a container class if it turns out to be appropriate. Often it turns out not to be, the smaller classes really don't have much to do with each other. 

GnuCash's conventional file layout (sadly honored in much in the breach as the observance) is to put the view code in a file pair named after the view, e.g. dialog-commodity.[ch] and the controller/adapter code in a separate file e.g. gnc-commodity-edit.[ch]. Adopting that separation and honoring the spirit would help make your implementation easier to understand.

Pretty good for a first foray into C++.

The main source of your early problems is not realizing the difference between passing by pointer, reference (a non-nullable pointer), and value. Returning values makes a copy of the return variable so assigning to it or one of its members doesn't change the value in the struct. The beauty of C++'s `&` and `auto` is that you need change only the return type of the accessor function and everything works as references with no copying.

Note that `auto&` works *only* when you're assigning from another variable, not from a function return.

Move semantics can be really complicated but the basic idea is that you're transferring the memory block owned by one variable to another variable instead of copying the contents from one to the other. After a move the donor variable's contents are undefined.

Skipping the GValue dance will hugely speed up KVP access. The example I provided could be made cleaner with some API work on QofInstance and KVP, but that's beyond the scope of this PR.

Too naive, because it's quite possible to have multiple transactions that are identical except for FITID. One example is a visit to the Apple Music store where one might buy several tunes or videos, each of which will appear as a separate line item with the same date, description, and price in the credit card account.

This adds a layer of complexity when what's actually required is removing a layer of complexity:

An Account has a split list. `xaccAccountForEachTransaction` traverses the split list and on every split `s` calls the callback with `split->parent`. The original version of `collect_trans_online_id` examined every split in the transaction for an online id and added those splits to the hash. Your change ignores every split in the transaction's split list except the one that belongs to the account. That split is `s`, the one it started with.

A much better fix would just traverse the Account's split list and hash the online ids.

So the Scheme language makes breaking API changes to their standard library by un-discussed pull requests. No committee, no formal process. Unbelievable. Even a cursory review by someone clueful would have caught that it should have been 
```
(cond ((null? (test-runner-group-stack r))
       (test-runner-current #f)
       ((test-runner-on-final r) r))))))
```
to preserve the return value of `test-runner-on-final` as the return of `test-end`.

After months I have finally found the time to look at this (and partly prompted because of PR #1247 ).

I think this is generally a very useful step forward. I've added a few remarks.

Considering this PR together with #1247 I am wondering if it would be worth abstracting the design into "a specialized combobox widget that lists reports and saved reports" (say `GncReportCombo`) so it could be reused in both use cases.

* This PR is about setting a default (saved) report to use for invoice printing. So it could use that more specialized combo box and build functionality around it to get or set a preference.
* PR #1247 on the other hand is about occasionally using **another** (saved) report to print a certain invoice (without making a detour via an invoice report window). That feature could also benefit from a more specialized combo box and use it to get a one-time value for a one-off (saved) report to use.

This doesn't have to be done as part of this PR necessarily though. I'm fine with the feature as implemented right now already (barring my few comments inline) and I think many users would be quite happy with this improvement.

Working towards a specialized combo box can be done as a next step. The data to store for this particular PR wouldn't change, only the code organisation would. (I'd be much more reluctant if a future adaptation would involve data changes).

I think you have made a good start here. However your initial work reveals much more inconsistencies than just the ones you have uncovered so far. So rather than go through each change you have made, I'll offer a overarching design suggestion to work towards:

### Vendor
![Vendor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/619393/125094594-b091d280-e0d3-11eb-96c8-a16c22d5aa01.png)

#### In the vendor dialog
* Change `Identification` to `Vendor Identification`. That gives enough context to the two enclosed fields we can drop `Vendor` and `Company` from `Number` and `Name` respectively.
* Change to `Vendor Address` instead of `Billing Address`. Vendors only have one address.
* `Payment Information` -> `Billing Information` for the second tab
* `Contact` -> `Contact Name` to clarify this is an optional name for a contact at t his address.

#### In the find  dialog
* Use `Number` and `Name` without their prefixes. From the context it should be clear these refer to the vendor number and name. Benefit of the shorter name will be smaller columns.
* Use `Contact Name` rather than just `Contact` to be consistent with the vendor dialog.

### Customer
![Customer](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/619393/125094596-b12a6900-e0d3-11eb-9f23-042bc77daaff.png)

The changes are much like for Vendor. As with vendors, the customer's primary address is called `Customer Address`. Customers however can optionally have a second address, the shipping address. So to disambiguate between the contact names in these two addresses in  the search  form there are `Contact Name` (which refers to the `Customer Address` contact name and `Shipping Contact Name` referring to the contact name on the shipping address.
I have deliberately not chosen `Customer Contact Name` to refer to the `Customer Address` because `Customer` is implied by the way the dialogs are designed now.

### Employee
![Employee](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/619393/125094601-b1c2ff80-e0d3-11eb-856b-afd5d0337413.png)

* Again changes similar to the other two, though with a few important distinctions. User name has simply become `Employee Identification` -> `Name`. According to @derekatkins `Username` was chosen with the idea in mind to add fine grained per user access controls to gnucash but that was never implemented. I also think if we ever implement that it should not be at the employee level. So opt here to bring this field in line with the same in vendor and customer. From that follows that the `Employee Address` -> `Name` also becomes the optional `Contact Name` again already in vendor and customer.
* Considering we have no implementation for access control, I also propose to drop the `Access Control` tab completely.
* To be consistent with vendors and customers the order of search parameters and result columns is changed to first show the `Employee Identification`->`Name` and end with `Contact Name`.


All these changes together should give us a more consistent user experience, reusing more terms than before (which means fewer translations), while retaining a space efficient result table.

There's two more issues:
1. A book with using the equity-type KVP and with opening balance accounts that aren't named Opening Balance in the user's language opened in an older version of GnuCash won't be able to find the right opening balance account so GnuCash will create a new one. We usually handle that with a feature flag and a two-phase introduction: The first phase recognizes the feature flag and can find opening balance accounts using `gnc_account_lookup_by_opening_balance`; the second phase in a later release can set the event-type KVP and the feature flag.
2. A user could rename an opening balance account to something else and not know that they need to set the opening balance flag. The first half of that is an existing problem, but it can be dealt with going forward by noticing the name and setting the flag automatically.

This PR doesn't cover all scenarios with payment transactions very well.

I see three possible scenarios:
1. payment txn has 0 associated invoices yet (a pre-payment)
2. payment txn has exactly one associated invoice
3. payment txn has more than one associated invoice

Each case has different behaviour:
1. The menu option should be disabled. There's nothing useful to show so don't offer the option.
2. Find the invoice and show it. This is regardless of whether the invoice is associated with the current split or any other split in the transaction. To find it there are a few mechanisms. The universal one is to loop over all APAR splits until you find one with an associated invoice. For invoice type txns a shortcut is to query the transaction itself for its associated invoice. I don't know if that optimization is still worth it.
3. The basic idea is to ask the user which invoice to display. You could still refine this and alter behaviour in case the split you clicked on for this action has an associated invoice itself. This is more or less what you have implemented now. I'm in two minds whether this specialization is really beneficial or rather confusing. It's much easier to educate users on the concept of the three rules above than having to explain why sometimes you can't select the invoice to jump to for multi-invoice payments and sometimes you can.

Anyway, much of the code will revolve around counting invoices in a transaction and determining the behaviour based on whether the number of invoices is 0, 1 or > 1.

While reviewing I couldn't help thinking it would be good user experience if the OFX importer was transformed into an assistant as the csv importer. The current importer does everything in separate windows that close and open. The steps are similar:
1. select a file or multiple files to import
2. (csv needs a preview step, but can be skipped for ofx)

5. summary

At the end of each step 4 you test whether there's still another file waiting. If so, jump back to step 3 with the new file. I think there is a small problem here in that you're not actually specifying the date that the balance is computed.  Specifically, the balance will be computed at the end of time, which might not be the "right" balance.  This is a problem in multiple ways:
1) If there are multiple SXes that fire, are you sure they are being inserted in order?  For example, let's say that the user went away for 3 months so has 3 mortgage payments fire simultaneously.  The first one might have the correct balance, but the next two probably wont.
2) If you're dealing with an asset account that has multiple transactions going, the way the balance is computed probably wont be correct, either.

In my mind the correct function to use is xaccAccountGetBalanceAsOfDate(), but then you need to ensure you plug in the correct date.  Also, you need to deal with the case of multiple-firing instances of SXes too.

Good you are working on this. The current state handling is a bit frustrating at times.

You bring up a good point with the default state for invoices and bills and I like to go a bit deeper into that.

With your additions we now save state for account registers, invoice windows and budgets.

Let's start with invoices and bills. There are 3 layouts really, invoice layout, bill layout and voucher layout. We also support credit notes but these just use the same respective layouts per type. Each of these layouts has a fixed number of columns which can't be changed.
Of all the fields, only the Description field can vary widely in content width. The others a few characters at most. I will assume that if a user changes any column other than the description column, chances are high this is because the current defaults aren't good - a date, amount, total,... doesn't fit due to particular font or style settings. On the other hand if the user changes the Description that may be because it doesn't fit too well for a particular document. I believe the former is much more likely than the latter.

Where I'm going with this is should we consider only allowing the user to save an updated default state rather than individual document states ?
Here is what I would propose for invoices, bills, etc:
* Add a menu item to set default state (you did). If the user clicks that, the state of the current document will be stored as default state and reused for all documents of the same type that will be opened subsequently. This will help in cases where a field is systematically too narrow or too wide.
* For the description use case (where it's too wide or narrow on a particular document) I would propose to save state of open documents separately. We already do so. There's a page group for each open document. In there we add the current column widths. That means the state will be lost when the user closes the document, but at the same time it will be saved across gnucash restarts. This is a different trade-off to guard against an exploding state file than yours (which was to drop state for paid documents). I think saving individual state on not currently opened invoices only for a description field that may or may not be too wide is a bit overkill. I'll go even further in that if it's too long to fit completely, in most cases the part that is visible will already hold enough information to understand what the entry was about. So showing the complete field is rarely needed.
* Have a menu item to reset the default state to built-in state.

And I'm actually inclined to apply the same reasoning to the account registers. The most common motivation to change field widths is a field that's systematically too narrow. So implementing defaults for registers would make a lot of sense. We should keep in mind though there are several register types with a varying number of columns. Of the top of my head there are at least
- the most basic register (denominated in a currency)
- a commodity register (which will has amount, price and share price fields)
- a business register (which will have a type field)
- a general ledger (though that may just be a variation of the ordinary register with detailed split view)
- ...
 So we'd need to save different defaults per register type. Other than that it can follow the same concept.

FWIW I used to compare gnucash with a spreadsheet when thinking of how to handle columns. There is a difference though: spreadsheets are completely free-form grids of cells. What information goes into which column can vary arbitrarily from page (tab) to page (tab). That doesn't apply to gnucash. The columns are strictly defined and the information presented in pages of the same type is very similar. In addition a spreadsheet typically only has a handful of tabs (or sheets) at most. However gnucash keeps track of hundreds of objects that can all be represented in a tab. So where in a spreadsheet it would make sense to store column information for each sheet (tab), it does much less so for gnucash IMO. Hence my strong preference to move to defaults per supported type.

Formatting note: We use 4-space indents, most of your code is 2-space. Please adjust it.

Aside from the technical suggestions there are a few design issues though - backward compatibility and user experience

First on the backward compatibility. Our policy so far has been that any data format change in a major release should be accompanied with changes in the most recent stable release in a way that that most recent stable release can at least still read the new format. It may not be able to write the new format, but it should be capable of reading the new format and writing the old format. With this "one time budget sign fix" we're in a bit of an awkward situation as it affects both data and reports together.

Assuming 3.8 is the most recent stable version that should be able to read the new budget data format, that would mean that version should be able to read both the old and the new format:
* users may be using 3.7 on other PC's and 3.8 should work well with that data.
* or users may be using 4.0 on another PC and 3.8 should be able to interpret 4.x's data correctly.

So 3.8 needs a way to determine which data format it's looking at and act accordingly. We can use your newly added feature check `GNC_FEATURE_BUDGET_UNREVERSED` to make this distinction. But contrary to what you did that means 3.8 should be made aware of this flag so it should already be defined in 3.8. The clever trick lies in the fact the 3.x series will *never* actively set that flag. Only 4.x will. That will ensure that once 4.x converts the data, gnucash versions older than 3.7 will refuse to work on that data. 3.8 and up on the other hand will, and can use the presence of the flag to determine how to interpret the budget data.

If the flag is unset, treat the data as old style (with fragile sign reversals) and handle it accordingly in reports. If the flag is set, handle the data as new style (with canonical data stored) and handle sign reversals only while displaying.

It gets a bit more complicated when users manipulate budget data in 3.8 after it had been converted to new style. Conceptually the budget data is supposed to be written back in the old format (3.8 should only be able to read the new format, remember?). We could do that in theory, provided the feature flag is reset when that happens. In practice though I think this will be fairly complex. When exactly do you change from one format to the other ? The moment the user enters a new value in the budget ? When the data is saved again ? In all situations it will be tricky to make all parts of the code switch at the same time from one format to the other. I think it to more elegant to decide the format at load time and stick to it (either after an initial conversion as 4.x does or just using it as is in 3.x).
The side effect of that choice would be that 3.8 should be capable of both reading and writing old and new formats *and* the reports should be able to display either format.

Aiming for backwards compatibility is a bitch unfortunately...


The second bit is user experience:

The backwards compatibility is one important aspect of this already of course.

Here are just a few other smaller considerations:

You have already determined two use cases in which the conversion should not be run:
- If it's already set
- If the book doesn't contain any budgets
There's a third case: when the user isn't reverting accounts at all. In the case we can assume all amounts are already stored properly. Rather than running over each account with the function gnc_reverse_balance to find one, you can simply check whether the user's preference is set to a value that reverses certain accounts. That's roughly the same check gnc_reverse_balance does as well, only more direct.

Next, the message provided to the user should be more elaborate. I think it should at least inform the user the old style data format was fragile wrt the account reversals necessitating a one-time fix. And it should make it clear that after applying the fix the data can't be opened anymore with versions of gnucash older the 3.8 (or whatever the first version will be that will be able to handle the new format).

And then there are more subtle issues:
- assume a user opens a pre-existing book that doesn't have any budgets yet in 4.x. Your current check will detect this and just skip any conversion attempt (and hence won't set the feature flag). The user now adds a budget (still in 4.x) and saves the book. Next restart gnucash. It will arrive again at this conversion check. The flag is not set, and at least one budget is present, so the conversion function is triggered. This is not what you want! The book was saved with gnucash 4.x so the budget values were already in the correct format and will now be inverted! To fix: the feature flag should also be set on save when the book contains at least one budget.
- a variation based one the third option: there are no reversed account because the user preference dictated this. Assuming this third test is added, opening this book in 4.x will skip conversion. At some point the user decides s/he prefers to use an account reversal strategy after all and changes the preference. Upon first opening the book again in 4.x the conversion will run as the flag was not set. You could argue this wouldn't happen if we just run the conversion at all times, regardless of the user's chosen account reversal strategy. That's right, however that would also mean that in many cases we prevent users from using an older version of gnucash that could before even though the data hasn't changed. So instead I would set or reset the feature flag whenever the user changes the account reversal strategy. If there are no account reversals reset the flag, otherwise set it.

Note the check for sign reverted accounts as third check assumes the user could have been sensibly using budgets with that user preference set in 3.x. I'm not sure that was actually the case as I haven't tested this. The above concept may need a few slight tweaks depending on the current state of budget issues in the 3.x series.

While you're in this area, can you improve the function to use report guids to manage the list of available reports instead of the detour via position in the list ?

I think that would reduce the number of round trips to scheme code making the code more readable *and* faster.

Regardless of guids vs row numbers (which I'll detail below), there's also no need to track selected lines. This information is readily available from the treeviews, at least until the tree models are cleared. So the functions related to tracking the selection can be removed and I suspect your first_run boolean can be replaced with whether you managed to extract a valid selection from the treeview (in row counting terms, set row to -1 to start, try to get the row number stored in the tree selection and check if this is still a valid number, if not set it to -1, then your selection loop should only run if selection is > -1. A similar strategy can be set up when using guids).

The guid story is that you store report guids (probably still most efficiently in SCM format) instead of row numbers in the tree store. With the changes as above you can start by extracting a guid from the existing tree selection. If there isn't one , set selection to SCM_UNDEFINED.

Then you rebuild the list store. For each line you add you can check that line's guid against your selection one. If it matches that's the line to select at some point (either directly or in a followup loop, see inline comment on this idea).

I think this slightly reduces the number or scm callouts.

Ideally this would also be done for the content liststore, but that may be a bit more tricky as it involves changing the options internals to return a list of guids instead of a list of line numbers (although perhaps there is a function that would do so. I haven't checked that part).

The guid based approach looks good. And I am fine with skipping the content tree view. It's tricky.

As for the different names this comes from the fact that the available reports list and the content reports list use a different source to extract the name: the former uses the report name while the latter uses the report's "name" option. The first can be altered in the saved report configurations window, the latter in the report options. We should align these and I'll see if I can find a way to extract the former from the report options as well.

While your solution works it's not the ideal workflow in that the user is "reprimanded" for entering wrong data. It would result in a much nicer user experience if the user would be prevented from entering invalid data in the first place.

For example if a date in the future is effectively not allowed you can automatically correct set the date to today after the user leaves the date entry field and inform the user you did via a status field or a (new to gtk3) [in-app notification](https://developer.gnome.org/hig/stable/in-app-notifications.html.en).
Similarly the start date can be set to the end date or the other way around if the user had entered them out of sequence together with a notification.

Do you think this is something you can work at ?

More in general though I wonder whether a dialog (now turned window) is really the best design choice for the function it fulfils. Perhaps I don't see all the use cases though so feel free to correct me.

The main use case I see is you can search for an account by typing part of the name to get a shorter list and then jump to that account. However one can directly type (part of) an account name when the account hierarchy is the front most window/page and it does this for you. If the text you typed is not unique you can use arrow up and arrow down to jump to the previous/next account that matches.

This is much faster and with much less user interruption.
The main drawback of this treeview feature is discoverability, which could be improved by adding a looking-glass type button in a carefully chosen spot.

The current find account window also presents additional booleans for the accounts, namely placeholder, hidden, unused, zero balance or tax related. Except for the hidden status, all the other could in some way be represented directly on the main account page in my opinion by playing with font style (for placeholder) or extra optional columns (unused, tax related). Zero balance is already visible.

As with the reconcile view suggestions I made, this is not something to consider for the 3.x series. But I would love to discuss this further at some point for 4.x.

On linux try the following:
1. select some arbitrary text anywhere on your system and hit ctrl-c to copy it to the clipboard
2. now select some other text
3. middle-click on the description field in gnucash

- click with middle mouse button again

When making changes which are associated to a bug report please use the bug report id and title as first line of the commit message. More details can be added starting from the third line.

Doing this has a few benefits: 
1. the one pushing your changes knows a bug has to be closed as well (and when git-bz is installed, this can be handled automatically even).
2. it's easier to scan for fixed bugs when generating a release

On a general note, I'm in two minds about your first two commits. While I do like the pervasive code reuse you manage there, I'm not sure It's done the right way.

You have now created an asymmetry between the transaction report (the base) and the GST report (the derived one). Because of this you have to tweak the the options you get from the transaction report in several non-obvious ways.

Can you instead abstract the common code into a common base object ("trans-report-base" for lack of a more inspired name)? This base just implements what's common in both reports. Then both reports derive from this and add their own unique options to it. That's cleaner OO design IMO, because it's now clear there's a base class for both and everything in that base class is valid for both.

Christopher, while I see value in this extra filter, you patch will need additional work because it may lead to incompatible saved reports state.

When someone saves a report based on your change with the "Account substring" option set and later wants to reopen it with an older version of gnucash (be it on another PC or because the current version is causing trouble), gnucash will fail to load the saved report due to an unknown option.

For this reason incompatible option changes

1. can only be done on master
2. backward compatibility code should be added to maint

The first part is a matter of applying your changes to the master branch and making a PR to master.
The second part means in addition to the master work, you'll need to add a PR to maint such that maint is aware of the new option. Maint may choose not to use the option, but it should resave it when set.

It looks like the GncPriceImport class is very similar to GncTxImport. I hoped my code would be reusable :)

However also here I would like a similar solution to GncImportSettings: create a base class with 2 derived classes.

The reason I would like to see this is that both classes share quite a bit of functionality, like setting file format, encoding. Other methods have the same intention but only work on different data. Or in other words both classes have a very similar interface.

By copying the file, you only make a snapshot of the interface and common functionality. If either class then makes changes in what could be common code or interface the other won't pick it up. So the classes would unintentionally drift apart over time. This risk is much less by explicitly writing it in code the classes adhere a common interface and by keeping common code written only once

A more general remark, I think it's worth renaming a number of files and classes to be more unified, starting with the settings classes. I propose to use file names like this:
gnc-imp-settings-<filetype>-<objecttype>.<ext>
So
gnc-imp-settings-csv-trans.cpp, gnc-imp-settings-csv.hpp (for the base class) and so on.
That will group the related source files closer together in the file browser.
And let's use similar names for the classes:
GncImpSettingsCsv, GncImpSettingsCsvTrans, GncImpSettingsCsvPrice

Be sure to do the renaming in a separate commit though.

@RaianRaika,

The implementation in gnc-date and gnc-datetime is backwards. Implement everything in **C++11** using a class hierarchy to provide calendar classes. Renam GncDateTimeImpl to GncGregorian create a new GncJalali subclass of GncDateTime. Provide a factory function that picks which one to instantiate based on the preference setting. gnc-jalali.h/c should be changed to gnc-jalali.hpp/cpp and should implement the GncJalali calendar class, using whatever of Christian’s old code that  you like, but translated into C++.

 The whole thing should be completely invisible to the C functions in gnc-date.cpp; gdate-utils will have to be converted to C++ (it can move to libqof too) so that it can call GncDateTime to do what it needs, and that will fix the problem of OS-provided date functions. We can't use them because 32-bit and LLP64 systems have a 32-bit time_t that fails for dates after mid-2038. gnc-date's time64 exists purely to work around that, but in GncJalali you can use boost::datetime directly.

Then there's GncCalendar. Rather than copying the whole thing into GnuCash, you should subclass GtkCalendar and override only the functions that you need to.

Aside from the design problem, some general issues:

Please reformat your code to meet our [coding standards](http://wiki.gnucash.org/wiki/CodingStandard). You may find [artistic style](http://astyle.sourceforge.net/) helpful; we use ```astyle --indent=spaces=4 --brackets=break --suffix=none``` that cleans up most of the problems.

Block comments should be enclosed with ```/* … */```; ```/**…*/``` for Doxygen comments.

You declare ```static``` functions in header files. That’s a major no-no. ```static``` functions have scope only in the file they’re defined in.
